required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Evaluating Changes in Middle Ear Pressure Caused by CPAP
clinical_study.official_title: Evaluating Changes in Middle Ear Pressure Caused by CPAP

brief_summary.textblock: This study is an investigation into the effect that CPAP has on the pressure in the middle ear. It will evaluate the middle ear pressure and ear drum appearance at multiple levels of CPAP pressure delivered via a full face mask. These measurements will be used to determine optimal levels of CPAP to affect individual's middle ear pressure, particularly those with negative middle ear pressure due to Eustachian tube dysfunction.

clinical_study.why_stopped: Study closed due to lack of participants

primary_outcome.description: Probes in the ear canal evaluate middle ear pressure

secondary_outcome.description: Patient reports if they felt their ears "pop"
A simple 7 question form regarding ear symptoms over the past month prior to trial involvement
An image of the ear drum is captured

arm_group.description: All participants will be included in this arm, and CPAP will be administered using a full face mask at incrementally increasing pressures. This will occur during a single session lasting no more than one hour.

intervention.description: A CPAP machine will be used to deliver positive pressure at various levels after which middle ear pressure and ear drums will be evaluated for changes.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Age >18
- No use of CPAP within past 30 days
- Individuals presenting to the UVA otolaryngology clinic who are otherwise healthy
Exclusion Criteria:
- Pre-existing cardiopulmonary disease that presents a risk with CPAP use
- Inability to tolerate CPAP
- Recent otologic surgery

reference.citation: Akbulut S, Demir MG, Salepci BM, Gungor GA, Demir N, Berk D, Cakan D. Efficacy of continuous positive airway pressure on middle ear atelectasis: A double-blind placebo-controlled clinical trial. Laryngoscope. 2016 Jul;126(7):1649-55. doi: 10.1002/lary.25735. Epub 2015 Oct 20.

Sivri B, Sezen OS, Akbulut S, Coskuner T. The effect of continuous positive airway pressure on middle ear pressure. Laryngoscope. 2013 May;123(5):1300-4. doi: 10.1002/lary.23896. Epub 2013 Apr 2.
